issues.title: Protection from theft
issues.author: kfet
issues.body:
A big contribution to the usefulness and popularity of AirTags (and similar tech) is the ability of their owners to track valuable items (cars, luggage, etc) in case they get stolen from their owners.

With the current specification it seems this use case is not considered, and any criminal with any compatible smart device (iOS/Android) will be allowed to detect such tracking and disable it 30m after stealing valuables.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body:
Hi @kfet,

That is one use-case for which these trackers are used, but it has never been the intended use-case. This specification does not make it easier to discover these trackers for thieves. AirTags, Samsung Trackers, Tile, they all rely on Bluetooth. Every simple Bluetooth scanner app can find them. 

The intended use-case was to find your lost valuables and that's where these devices are great at. The added protection against stalking is helpful for people who are in threat of stalking. Stalking can lead to harmful attacks and have already ended up in at least two people getting killed after they have been tracked with an AirTag. The value of any material device should never be higher than the value of human life.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
Hello @Sn0wfreezeDev, thanks for responding!

> Stalking can lead to harmful attacks and have already ended up in at least two people getting killed after they have been tracked with an AirTag. The value of any material device should never be higher than the value of human life.

This is implied. However it should not be an excuse to ignore how other use-cases are affected.

I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property. Just as a very trivial example to start-off such conversation it could be made possible for authorities to recover details of the device used to disable a tracker, it it gets reported as tracking stolen property. If nothing else this could discourage theft.

> This specification does not make it easier to discover these trackers for thieves. 

I think this is not true. This spec will make it trivially easy, by having a tracker work with any smart phone to proactively notify a thief of the tracker's presence, AND allowing it to get disabled, with zero effort on their part, no additional equipment or app required.

At the very least it seem to me the effect on this use case should be acknowledged as a side-effect.

comments.author: mrlnc
comments.body:
> I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property.

I think [Section 2: Applicability](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers-00.html#name-applicability-2) goes in that direction; unwanted tracking countermeasures are required only for small items (with high potential for misuse). *Find My* enabled suitcases, bicycles or cars (with the tracker *built-in*) could remain silent.

Is my understanding correct?

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: Yes that's the way how Apple has internally defined that for participants of the Find My Network already. You can find leaked documents about this online.

comments.author: Guggie30
comments.body: After experiencing the theft of my wallet, I purchased a new one which has the capability of holding an AirTag in it.  I also add AirTags to my briefcase and hide them inside my luggage lining.  I’m concerned that these benefits  will be rendered useless if proposed specifications do not allow for this popular usage.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: We are actively developing an iOS and an Android App that can detect virtually any tracker that is out there. Our goal is stalking and unwanted tracking protection and its a state funded university project. You can already expect that a thieve would be able to find the AirTag in your wallet.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body: You are assuming 100% adoption of your app on all Android and iOS devices. This is not a realistic assumption.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: No, I do not assume that. That's why I am in favor of this proposal, because that will lead to the adoption needed to fight unwanted tracking. However, I assume that knowledgable people that are concerned of unwanted tracking (e.g. politians, journalists, etc.) can inform themselves and use these tools to protect themselves. The same I assume for organized thieves.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
>... The same I assume for organized thieves.

Jumping from "it is possible with knowledge" to "everyone will know how to do this" is a huge leap, especially when talking about petty theft, and random un-targeted street crimes, like stealing wallets and suite cases.

I don't see substance so far behind the claim that trackers provide no protection from such crimes, because everyone would already know how to detect and disable the tracker, even without this specification. This is not a realistic assumption for the general public, criminal or not.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
> > I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property.
> 
> I think [Section 2: Applicability](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers-00.html#name-applicability-2) goes in that direction; unwanted tracking countermeasures are required only for small items (with high potential for misuse). _Find My_ enabled suitcases, bicycles or cars (with the tracker _built-in_) could remain silent.
> 
> Is my understanding correct?

Thanks for pointing this out, I read the section, and the intent is unrelated. It specifies the best practices as required for items small enough to be hidden undetected, which absolutely makes sense, but it doesn't address the general concern discussed in this issue, like the fact that a lot of valuables one would hope to recover are small enough to match this requirement - think wallets with IDs and credit cards, or passport holders.

comments.author: gillian-epm
comments.body: Hi Kalin, it’s true that this tradeoff exists, and if you implement this spec this should be taken into consideration. Prioritizing protections against unwanted tracking is the position we (Google and Apple) have taken; as others have commented above, AirTag is specifically intended to be used for tracking lost items, not for recovering stolen items.  Accessory makers who implement the spec should be aware of this tradeoff and understand its implications on the theft detection scenario.

issues.title: Clarification on the threat model of location-trackers
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


“First, I think it's important to be clear on the threat model
here. The threat from "finder" type location trackers like
Tiles or AirTags comes from the interaction of a number of features,
specifically:

1. They are compact (thus easy to hide)
2. They are cheap (thus easy to obtain)
3. They take advantage of a preexisting infrastructure intended
   for another purpose (the finder network)
4. They have long battery lifetimes (and thus are suitable
   for long-term surveillance)

To contextualize this, consider the counter example of a GPS tracker
like a Garmin inReach, which takes a GPS location and broadcasts it to
a satellite. These cost about $300, have battery life measured in days,
and are several centimeters across, so are hard to conceal. This is
much less useful for both covert surveillance and for finding ones
own items. So, the objective of this work should be to the extent
possible to prevent attacks which are cheaper than buying your
own GPS tracker.”

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
It sounds like these are all good nuances to add to the applicability section. Currently that only talks about what makes something "easily discoverable"

> Accessories are considered easily discoverable if they meet one of the following criteria: 
> - The item is larger than 30 cm in at least one dimension. 
> - The item is larger than 18 cm x 13 cm in two of its dimensions. 
> - The item is larger than 250 cm3 in three-dimensional space.

It sounds like the cost/availability, battery life, and connectedness model are all dimensions that would be good to add.

issues.title: UT detection countermeasures
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


“Second, I think it's important to consider the situation with
nonconformant tracking tags. There are several attacks here,
including:

1. Modifying an existing tage to make it nonconformant in
   such a way that the countermeasures in this draft don't
   work.
2. Making a new tag which is nonconformant, etc.

I think this framing is useful when considering two different sets
of countermeasures in this design:

1. The "sound maker" feature of having the device make noise when its
   separated and moving (S 3.12.2.1) or when it is located
   (S 3.12.3).

2. The BT-based "this device is following me" feature described in
   S 3.4.3.

The key point I would like to make here is that countermeasure
(1) is potentially evaded without compromising the above invariants.
For instance, maybe I can take an AirTag and disable the speaker
in some way but it will still work for location tracking. Or
maybe I can wrap it in some sound insulating material. Clearly I
can fix the flashing lights. None of this seems like it impacts
the basic tracking functionality, including the surveillance
use case.

By contrast, I don't think it's necessarily feasible to easily modify
the tracker to use some different protocol that would still be
compatible with tracking but harder to detect (e.g., faster ID rotation)
because that would depend on changing the firmware. So that is
a harder attack to mount, especially if the firmware is signed.
Obviously you can burn out the radio or wrap it in a faraday cage,
but that breaks *both* tracking and unwanted tracking detection.
However, it might be able to build a fake tag which violated
these invariants.

My point here is that detection countermeasures need to depend
on properties of the system that are hard to subvert while
having it continue to be functional. “

issues.title: Overall UT System Description
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)

“Finally, this document really focuses on how to detect unwanted
tracking but doesn't describe how the system as a whole works.
That makes it difficult to understand the overall context and
in particular to determine which invariants in this design are
enforced by the tracking network (and thus presumably harder
to evade) and those which are enforced by compliant tag behavior
(and thus may be easier to evade). A future version of this
document would be more useful if it described how the system
worked in its "as designed" configuration. This would also
allow evaluating its other security and privacy properties.”

issues.title: location-enabled state assumptions
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


S 3.3.
>   The accessory SHALL maintain an internal state that determines when
>   its location is, or has been, available to the owner via a network.
>   This state is called the location-enabled state.

“Are you making any assumptions about who can turn on this state?
E.g., does it have to be a paired device or can it be the network.”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Good callout! I admit the original thinking is that only the accessory could determine this state, but I don’t see any big concerns about the paired device or the network determining this state. However, in the network-controlled case, I think we’d need the control message to originate from one of the owner’s devices and the delivery to the accessory to be private and secure.

issues.title: UT detection and proximity to owner’s phone
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


>   It is RECOMMENDED that the location-enabled payload is only
>   advertised when the accessory is in the separated state.  The
>   reasoning behind this recommendation is that unwanted tracking
>   detection relies on the Bluetooth LE advertisements emitted while in
>   the location-enabled state to determine if an unknown accessory is
>   traveling with someone who is not the owner.  If the location-enabled
>   payload is advertised only in the separated state, that minimizes
>   false-positive UT alerts.

How does this interact with cases where I have lost something in
a location near my phone (e.g., in my house.  ?

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Good question! One way this could work is that your phone relays the lost item’s location between your own devices, but not over the finder network.

issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)

S 3.5.

>   unlinkable; otherwise, if the same address is used for long periods

comments.body: Agreed — perhaps it would be clearer to describe the randomness requirements as opposed to calling it broadly "unlinkable"?

comments.author: yannick-sierra
comments.body: I think the intent is for the addresses to be unlinkable by all but the owner devices, who need a way to recognize their own accessories. Agreed this could be made clearer.

issues.title: track-ability when in near-owner state
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


S 3.5.1.
>   When in near-owner state, the accessory SHALL rotate its resolvable
>   and private address every 15 minutes.  This is a privacy
>   consideration to deter tracking of the accessory by non-owners when
>   it is in physical proximity to the owner.

“Can you still track a device in this state?”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Not 100% sure I follow the question, so gonna try to clarify the intent of the section. In this state, the accessory’s location can still be determined by the owner’s devices (not the network). The unwanted tracking detection algorithms will not track the accessory in this state, because it’s in the near-owner state.

The word “tracking” referred to in the second sentence is for BT-scanner-based tracking that looks for an address that is static over a long period of time (>> 15 min).

So, maybe should rephrase this to:

"When in near-owner state, the accessory SHALL rotate its resolvable and private address every 15 minutes. This is a privacy consideration to deter long-term tracking of the accessory when it is in physical proximity to the owner."

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
Yes, my question was whether the owner could still track the device using the network. I.e., do nearby devices still publish reports to the network?

With that said, I don't think the use of the term "tracking" with that limited meaning is helpful here. It's all tracking.

issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


> 5.  Firmware Updates
>
> The accessory SHOULD have firmware that is updatable by the owner.

“This seems bad for the reasons above.”

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
The 'reasons above' that I am interpreting from Eric:

* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/6
* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/12
* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/8

comments.author: ekr
comments.body: Well, more generally, if you can update the firmware, you can cause the tag to just violate all the rules in this document.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Although I suppose in general, these tag devices need to be benevolent in the first place to participate in this to begin with — implementers could choose to violate the rules in any version, right? It sounds like the danger is that a product that is sold and is known to be compatible with these anti-tracking protocols could later get a malicious update. The question is if that risk is worse than the risk of not being able to update and being vulnerable to an attack due to an unpatched security flaw.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
Well, I think that this basically is a function of the overly narrow threat model of this document. which is that it doesn't address how to prevent the creation of a malicious device which uses the network.

See: https://educatedguesswork.org/posts/unwanted-tracking/#the-broader-threat-model

issues.title: non-owner controls should only be enabled in separated mode
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Sun, 07 May 2023 20:06 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


The non-owner controls specified in S 3.12.4 should probably only be
enabled
in separated mode. It would obviously be quite annoying if I could cause any
tag near me to start emitting noise.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
Agree that non-owner controls shall only be available when in separated mode.

Below Table 11 in 3.12.4 there is this statement:

“This control point SHALL be available to the platform only when the accessory is in separated state. In all other states, ..."
 
I propose moving this paragraph above Table 11 so it's not as separated from the rest.

comments.author: mrlnc
comments.body:
Hi all, thanks for the clarification here - I'm following the UT discussion and appreciate the public process. I was trying to find out if playing sounds should be possible when the accessory is in *near-owner* state, and I found Section 3.12.3 confusing.

Section 3.12.3 "Sound Maker" currently reads:

> The accessory MUST include a sound maker (for example, a speaker) to play sound ***when in separated state***, either periodically or when motion is detected.
> It MUST ***also*** play sound when a non-owner tries to locate the accessory by initiating a play sound command from a non-owner device when the accessory is in range and connectable through Bluetooth LE.

This section initially gave me the impression that playing sounds is always possible when in-range (both near-owner and separated state), and it seemed to contradict the statement in 3.12.4. Perhaps the Sound Maker section could emphasise that non-owner initiated sounds require the separated state ("when the accessory is in range and ~connectable through Bluetooth LE~ *in separated mode.*")

This issue seems to be the right place to share my confusion :-)

issues.title: MAC address format
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
// originally from josselin=[40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org](mailto:40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org) on May 11th, 2023
// via [unwanted-trackers@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers@ietf.org)

2: MAC addresses

The following requirement in 3.5:
"""
The Bluetooth LE advertisement payload SHALL contain a resolvable and
   private address for the accessory which is the 6-byte Bluetooth LE
   MAC address.
"""
is out of scope of this document. The scope of the document does not require a specific MAC address format to be used and this should be an implementation choice.

issues.title: Advertising interval
issues.author: bledvina

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Seems like adding a justification is a good idea! 

Here are some initial thoughts:

On the lower bound of the advertising interval, we probably want to add the fastest possible rate in which BT LE advertises for completeness and consistence. 

On the upper bound of the advertising interval, the reason to have a value that is not too large is:
a. Probability of detection: The longer the advertising interval, the harder it will be to reliably detect if an accessory is traveling with you 
b. User experience: Time-to-connect for non-owner play sound is a function of the advertising interval. I don't think we'd want users waiting a very long time to connect to locate an accessory that may be tracking them

comments.author: josselindlb
comments.body:
Agreed to not provide a lower bound limit.

About upper bound:
Our understanding is that time to discover or time to connect connect increase linearly with the advertising interval at close to medium range and staying under 4 seconds provides acceptable latencies for item trackers.
In the scope of this spec, close to medium range could be assumed and thus a 4s seconds limit could be used. Interested to hear about potential different findings on this.

issues.title: Availability for law enforcement
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
// Originally from alexis@eff.org on May 15th, 2023
// via unwanted-trackers@ietf.org

''''
3.15.3.  Availability for law enforcement

  The pairing registry SHALL be made available to law enforcement upon
  a valid law enforcement request.
''''

Since this a protocol for how a location tracker should behave for proper detection, this section is out of scope. This appears to dictate on what should happen with law enforcement access on what happens *after detection*, thus the protocol completing it's task and afterwards the user deciding on whatever action to take.

I anticipate language about law enforcement would appear somewhere in the usage of user establishing a tracker for use (benign or malicious), but strongly suggest addressing law enforcement access should be stricken from the scope of the specification.

comments.author: zoracon
comments.body: Just leaving a note here that there will be a follow up to this to possibly offer language on law enforcement requests.

comments.author: zoracon
comments.body:
Here is the updated text proposed for law enforcement. So yes, this is in conflict with my previous statement but I was willing to draw it back after a conversation with my colleagues.

"Additionally, unwanted physical trackers should be accountable. Manufacturers should store the bare minimum of information about the phone or account that the tracker is paired to, and they should store it for a time and in a manner consistent with their data retention policies. The information should be made available to others only in response to a valid court order."

issues.title: addition of "Shipment/Package" to accessory category values list
issues.author: bdetwiler

comments.author: gillian-epm
comments.body: Hi Elliot, is it your expectation that the shipping packages would have bluetooth tracking capability built into the package itself?  Or do you expect to be placing a BT tracker into the box?

comments.author: elliotklein
comments.body:
Hi Gillian, Bluetooth monitoring for packages/shipments under the draft spec is very low cost and essentially can provide worldwide location exception monitoring for important packages. In the envisioned use case(s) the device would be placed inside a package (or potentially outside too). The value is more in **exception** monitoring, not "tracking" to know when ETA is missed by package not being in designated geofence or location(s) or other misdirected or lost package event(s) occur to then trigger a notification Ideally, by an appropriate API. 

Most value is for B2B market in monitoring shipment(s)...from high-value medical shipments, to one of a kind samples, vaccines, high value medical or biological tissue samples,, or food products that under pending U.S. and E.U. regulations will need to be location monitored for chain of custody audit and/or food safety.  

Assigning a unique category code can potentially not be only for B2B enterprise markets or other authorized shipment use cases or registered shippers (UPS, US Postal, etc.) where a unique profile is associated with the Bluetooth tag/device to better assure privacy or functionality to prevent unwanted tracking with an appropriate API or interface(s) to be developed or potentially possible in the future.

issues.title: Time until unwanted tracking notification becomes active and potential nuisances
issues.author: siddikaparlak
issues.body:
From: [phil@aukilabs.com](mailto:phil@aukilabs.com)
To: authors of draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers, [nils@aukilabs.com](mailto:nils@aukilabs.com)
On: June 7, 2023


How long is the time before the unwanted tracking notification becomes active? Working on the assumption that this needs to be early enough to prevent sensitive location data (such as home address) from being obtained, could there be the potential for nuisance triggering in crowded spaces such as public transport? Could this also lead to people falsely flagging a genuine tag as being nefarious?

comments.author: siddikaparlak
comments.body: Since this draft focuses mainly on the accessory makers, it is out of scope to specify a time to notify the user about unwanted tracking. The time required for unwanted tracking detection may rely on several factors such as the user's movement pattern and mitigations to prevent false alerts.

issues.author: siddikaparlak
issues.body:
From: [phil@aukilabs.com](mailto:phil@aukilabs.com)

On: June 7, 2023


2. A number of the categories listed in section 4.  Accessory Category Value would imply that the accessory is used for asset tracking.  Can you explain how the system would determine the difference between unwanted tracking and theft?

issues.title: Location reporting after tag is detected as nefarious
issues.author: siddikaparlak
issues.body:
From: [phil@aukilabs.com](mailto:phil@aukilabs.com)
To: authors of draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers, [nils@aukilabs.com](mailto:nils@aukilabs.com)
On: June 7, 2023


My understanding is that once a tag is separated from its owner, any device in range can report its position. If a person detects and flags a tag as nefarious, does this prevent other devices in range from updating the location?

comments.author: siddikaparlak
comments.body: Once a tag is separated from its owner, other devices in range can update its location. If a tag was identified as nefarious, it must be physically disabled for location updating to stop (See Section 3.13).

comments.author: siddikaparlak
comments.body: This draft focuses on how to make tracking devices (like tags) detectable for unwanted tracking purposes and the changes that accessory makers can apply to do so. Altering the behavior of location-tracking software on a phone is out of scope for this draft, though perhaps there are additional forums where this is discussed.

issues.title: Endpoint Validation for FindMy to Prevent Surreptitious Tracking
issues.author: cfossace
issues.body:
Currently, there is no endpoint validation for FindMy, so the FindMy protocol provides transit for ALL traffic, even unwanted or malicious traffic. 

This means is that anyone can use FindMy to place a tracker on someone (that is not an AirTag) **_so it will NOT be detected by Apple's anti-tracking framework._** 

There needs to be some kind of endpoint validation to ensure that only legitimate Apple devices (or trackers that have been developed by official Apple developers using the FindMy Developer Program) are enrolled.   

1) **POC for registering non-Apple endpoints to the FindMy network to be geolocated by FindMy protocol** https://github.com/seemoo-lab/openhaystack


2) **POC for circumventing anti-tracking framework that allows malicious actors to surreptitiously track people** 
https://samteplov.com/uploads/who-tracks-the-trackers/trackers.pdf

3) **Potential Endpoint registration approach that also preserves user privacy** https://petsymposium.org/popets/2023/popets-2023-0006.pdf

issues.title: Minor clarification on location-enabled state text (section 3.3)
issues.author: maggiedelano
issues.body:
Thanks for your work on this document, and for soliciting feedback.

Minor suggested clarification: in section 3.3, the report says:

> The accessory SHALL maintain an internal state that determines when its location is, or has been, available to the owner via a network. This state is called the location-enabled state.

The use of the verb "determines" is a little confusing here. I think what you mean is it "detects" when the location is, or has been, available. Determines to me implies that the internal state itself is controlling whether it is in the location-enabled state.

issues.title: Supporting active scanning for unwanted tracking
issues.author: maggiedelano
issues.body:
Thanks for your work on this document, and for soliciting feedback.

I did some research on Apple AirTags last year, and one of the things that surprised me was how difficult it was to detect an AirTag using a [standard bluetooth scanner](https://www.maggiedelano.com/2022/02/21/apple-airtags-active-scanning.html) on iOS. It was much easier on Android, and unless it has changed recently there is no way to actively scan for AirTags on iOS (although it was in a beta at some point?). There are many contexts where a user would prefer to be able to actively scan their environment for unwanted trackers, rather than relying on a passive notification (which can take hours to occur).

I understand that platform issues are out of scope for this document, so I'll focus my other comments more specifically here too. Could the authors share the above concerns/suggestions with the relevant iOS team?

This document proposes an advertisement payload (section 3.4) that would allow "platforms to easily scan for and detect the location-enabled Bluetooth advertisement" (section 3.6). From what I can tell this is close to what AirTags already do. A few questions/comments:

- Will the service data TLV be standardized across location trackers? (I'm assuming yes but part of that section is marked TODO)
- It would be helpful to have some context on what existing location trackers already do and how/whether this is codification of what existing trackers e.g. AirTags already do, vs. a new proposed advertisement packet. I think the existing one works fine but the iOS platform is an issue for active scanning right now as I discuss above.
- I think section 6 should encourage (if not require) platforms to support both active and passive scanning. There should also be some discussion about appropriate time frames for passive notification (getting notified hours later is not helpful, but at the same time false positives need to be avoided).

pulls.title: Open to Third-Party Developers
pulls.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
pulls.body:
The current version of the document needs to clarify how a platform handles third-party developers. 
We want to ensure that platforms must not limit access to accessories following unwanted tracking specifications. Third-party developers must be able to scan for accessories, connect to them and interact with them over the accessory non-owner characteristic. 

The current version of the document is based on Apple's tracking detection for iOS, which is an excellent solution for most people. Nevertheless, there may exist different target groups that have different needs. For example, a police officer can be required to perform a detailed scan of the environment to detect any nearby trackers. It would be possible for a third-party developer to implement such a service and offer it on the App Store / Google Play Store. 

Furthermore, users might need more detailed settings. A user that has previously experienced stalking might want to be alerted earlier and is okay with experiencing a higher false-positive rate. 

Therefore, I propose the added changes to ensure that no platform or manufacturer limits access to the Bluetooth accessories following this specification.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
Hi @Sn0wfreezeDev 

Thank you for the feedback.

The primary goal of this internet draft is to outline the protocols and standards for location-tracking accessory makers to comply with platforms' unwanted tracking services. The "Platform Support for Unwanted Tracking” section is intended to standardize the model where accessory makers shall make a software extension available for the platforms to allow owner’s of their accessories to suppress UT alerts from their own paired accessories.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body: Thank you for this PR. As noted above, these additional requirements are beyond the scope of this document. If there are additional ideas in this area, please open an issue for discussion.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body:
I see that this might go beyond the current scope. Unfortunately, I know that Apple is blocking certain Bluetooth advertisements from third-party applications. There may be valid reasons to do so and that's why I tried to implement a section that would disallow platform owners to block the advertisements and access to other data sent out by these trackers. 

As you might already know, we are developing the AirGuard app that is used to perform the currently missing tracking detection for a variety of trackers: Samsung SmartTag, Tile, Chipolo + Find My Trackers on Android. 
When platforms can detect these automatically, we are more than happy because it brings protection to more people. However, there may be issues where a platform integration might lack support of specific features, like manual scanning. My approach to opennes was to ensure that these features can be implemented by third-parties, like us or other people.

pulls.title: Jb pairing address
pulls.author: josselindlb
pulls.body:
Hi there,

I was not sure how much bundling is usually done in PRs, so I ended up bundling some, especially as these are related in some cases. This PR provides addresses the following:

1. Disambiguate "Pairing" and use "association" instead where applicable (issue #17 ).
2. Not require a given MAC address format (issue #18 ).
3. When not in separated mode, require to rotate the MAC "at least every 120 minutes" instead of "every 15 minutes": the rational is that 120 should be good enough so we don't really need to require 15 minutes (of course 15 mn would be allowed).
4. Make the "Paired (Associated) Accessory Identification" mandatory instead of optional for platforms to support: the rational is that the experience would be poor if this is not supported by platforms.

Thanks,
Josselin
